title: 5 Real Ways Eggs Can Supercharge Your Dietary Health
author: Zee Krstic
description: After years of conflicting research, experts cut through the noise to share real facts.
cleaned_text: The real nutritional value of eggs in our diets has been long debated among health experts, as conflicting research has led to some misinformation around [this breakfast staple.](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/food-recipes/easy/g428/easy-egg-recipes/) Usually, cholesterol content within eggs is scrutinized — [a 2019 research review](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/2728487) highlighted a link between eggs' cholesterol content and increased risk of cardiovascular disease, a pattern reflected in [other peer-review studies](https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000743). But the latest U.S. Department of Agriculture's [ Dietary Guidelines for Americans](https://www.dietaryguidelines.gov/sites/default/files/2020-12/Dietary_Guidelines_for_Americans_2020-2025.pdf) still list eggs as part of a balanced, healthy diet. So what's the truth about the real nutritional value of eggs in your diet? The answer depends on how many eggs you eat every week. The same Journal of the American Medical Association review hinges on data sourced from Americans who eat as many as a dozen eggs per week — you shouldn't think twice about eggs in your diet unless you eat upwards of four per day. A separate [Harvard University School of Public Health](https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2020/03/moderate-egg-consumption-gets-the-green-light-again/) review published in 2020, which analyzed data collected from 215,000 men and women over a 34-year period, indicated that one egg on a daily basis led to a healthier diet for those without preexisting conditions. [A wholesome diet](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/a38305967/best-diets-2022/) is bolstered by eggs due to their protein content, but also thanks to essential nutrients like vitamins A, D, B12 and [the under-the-radar choline](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/a30572716/choline-health-benefits/). We're outlining the best dietary health benefits associated with eggs below, including their nutritional values, and tackling FAQ about eggs after the jump (including information on egg whites!). Egg Nutrition Stats A single large egg that's been hard-boiled contains the following, according to [the USDA](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/171287/nutrients): - 72 calories - 0g carbohydrates - 6g protein - 5g total fat - saturated fat (8% DV) - fiber vitamin A - 41 IU vitamin D (11% DV) Protein Eggs are a complete protein, containing all 9 essential amino acids necessary to rebuild muscles and tissues in our bodies. Depending on its size, one egg has anywhere between 5 to 8g of protein — and nearly every function in our bodies requires protein for power. That makes a constant supply of the essential amino acids, well, essential! Carbohydrates When prepared correctly, a breakfast made with eggs can be extremely light on carbohydrates, as each large egg contains about .33g of total carbohydrates on its own. With just a small amount of naturally occurring sugar, eggs are essential for those who may be working their way through special low-carb diets, [including Ketogenic programs](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/a19660747/list-of-keto-diet-foods/). Fat You may be surprised to learn that egg dishes often get a bad rap for saturated fat that may not be deserved; often, it is the way they are prepared (like fried in a pool of butter, for example!) that can add additional fat to the overall dish. Most of the 5g of monounsaturated fat within a large egg, including 1.5g of saturated fat, is contained within the yolk. If you're facing cardiovascular health issues, opting for egg whites may allow you to enjoy a similar amount of protein without any worries about saturated fats. Vitamins and Minerals Eggs may be one of the most nutritionally dense items in your fridge when it comes to vitamins and minerals: About 11% of your [daily intake of vitamin D](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/a40983846/vitamin-d3-benefits/) can help to better absorb calcium and strengthen your bones as well as boost immunity. Vitamin A can help [stimulate healthy skin growth](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/g1191/foods-for-younger-skin/), and choline is especially crucial for optimal eye health and for pregnant or expectant mothers, who are often not consuming enough choline for optimal development. Eggs' Health Benefits: Eggs can boost brain health. Eggs are chock full of choline, an essential nutrient crucial for healthy memory, mood, and muscle control, says [Michelle Hoeing Bauche](https://www.instagram.com/nutchelle.nutrition/?hl=en), MS, RDN, a clinical dietitian in the bariatric services division of the [University of Missouri Health Care](https://www.muhealth.org/locations/missouri-bariatric-services) system. "Choline is in the B vitamin family ... and is fairly 'new' compared to other nutrients that have been studied and researched," she says. "Consuming choline through foods like eggs may actually help to prevent things like cardiovascular disease, early brain dysfunction such as dementia, and fatty liver disease." But you won't get choline's health edge [by simply taking supplements](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/g27269358/best-multivitamins-for-women/); Bauche says that some research shows that choline on its own doesn't have much of an effect on preventing these conditions, most likely "because most nutrients act synergistically with one another and rarely alone." Your best bet is to incorporate choline-rich foods into regular rotation in the kitchen. Eggs and other dairy items are the best source, Bauche says, followed by beef liver, shiitake mushrooms, [fatty-rich salmon](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/food-recipes/healthy/g448/salmon-recipes/), and beans, legumes, and cruciferous vegetables on a smaller scale. Eggs can help to maintain weight loss over time. Research has linked meals higher in protein to the ability to [keep you fuller, longer.](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/g28567696/best-high-protein-low-carb-foods/) Published in the [Journal of the American College of Nutrition](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15466943), a 2004 review suggests that protein-rich foods (including eggs!) are the most filling option available at mealtime, even with smaller portions compared to other nutrients. Plus, lean proteins like eggs are often lower in calories compared to higher-fat cuts of meat and poultry. Eggs safeguard pregnancy development. During pregnancy, choline intake is critical for fetal brain development and can help prevent birth defects. "Research suggests that as many as 90% of pregnant women may not be consuming adequate amounts of choline," Bauche says, adding that clinical studies have found that pregnant women who eat upwards of 900mg of choline (double the recommended daily intake) may boost cognitive development in their children later on. "While most people are aware [that folate plays a role](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health-products/g28186970/best-prenatal-vitamins/) in preventing neural tube defects, choline actually plays an equally important role, since it also aids in the synthesis of cell membranes and neurotransmission." Two large eggs contain more than 50% of the recommended choline intake for pregnant women. [Vitamin B12](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/g1967/vitamin-b12-super-foods-47012607) is another essential nutrient required for red blood cell formation, neurological function, and DNA synthesis. B12 is almost exclusively found naturally in animal products, so if you're vegetarian, eggs can help meet your B12 needs. Eggs can help preserve vision and eye health. Eggs also contain a crucial chemical compound known as carotenoids that are normally found in fruits and vegetables — and these nutrients can help [boost the immune system over time](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/a26040273/immune-boosting-foods/), according to [Anne-Marie Gloster](https://epi.washington.edu/faculty/gloster-anne-marie), Ph.D., R.D., a lecturer in the nutritional sciences program at [the University of Washington](https://nutr.uw.edu/). "Carotenoids are the chemical compounds which produce the yellow, orange, and red colors in fruits and vegetables," she shares, adding that eggs contain a class of carotenoids known as xanthophylls. "The two xanthophyll compounds found in these carotenoid-rich foods are lutein and zeaxanthin; they are more of the yellow pigments in our foods. Egg yolks contain these xanthophylls ... And the color of [the] yolk is dependent on the feed of the chicken and whether their diet included carotene-rich foods." The lutein and zeaxanthin found in eggs play a role in maintaining eye health; [research published in 2019](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6629295/) shows that lutein in particular may impact cognition in both children and adults. Gloster shares that these pigments allow our eyes to naturally [filter blue-light emissions from computers](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/a20707076/blue-light-glasses/) and televisions; research has suggested that these compounds may even help prevent declining vision into old age and cataracts themselves. And while eating a balanced diet usually provides more than enough of these chemical compounds for your body to absorb, Gloster says eggs provide far more immediate benefit than most leafy vegetables. " Because eggs also contain fatty acids, the lutein and zeaxanthin is more bioavailable, more easily absorbed, than the richer vegetable sources of carotenoids." Eggs help to build healthier bones. Eggs are one of the few natural sources of [vitamin D](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/advice/a26805/vitamin-d-benefits/), which helps with absorbing calcium, maintaining healthy bones, promoting neuromuscular function, and reducing inflammation. "Other essential nutrients and vitamins found in eggs include DHA (higher amounts from pasture-raised chickens), other B vitamins, fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K," Bauche says. "The trace minerals iodine and selenium are often forgotten about or not usually consumed in sufficient amounts, but they do play a role in brain development, thyroid function, and liver function." Eggs and Cholesterol Levels: Current evidence indicates that dietary cholesterol does not automatically raise our blood cholesterol, meaning eating moderate amounts of eggs does not appear to affect disease risks in most healthy people. A review of previously published studies, [published in ](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2728487) [JAMA](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2728487) by a team of researchers at Northwestern University, suggests that eating more than 3 eggs a week may raise the risk of heart disease by upwards of 25%. But many experts have conceded that dietary cholesterol isn't as damaging to long-term health as saturated and trans fats, which can have a more serious effect on blood cholesterol. The [2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans](https://www.dietaryguidelines.gov/sites/default/files/2020-12/Dietary_Guidelines_for_Americans_2020-2025.pdf) as well as the American Heart Association, the American College of Cardiology, and the American Diabetes Association have removed previous recommendations to limit dietary cholesterol, as modest, manageable amounts occur naturally in a balanced diet. The bottom line? Eating eggs in moderation is key, especially if you are already combating high cholesterol — a four-egg omelet daily will have an immediate effect on your cardiovascular health, but an egg or two can definitely [be part of a healthy breakfast](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/food-recipes/easy/g871/quick-breakfasts/). Are brown eggs healthier than white eggs? Nope! The color of an egg is not an indicator of quality, nutrition, or taste. Rather, the color depends on the breed of the hen, Bauche says. White-feathered hens lay white eggs, while brown-feathered hens lay brown eggs. If you're wondering why brown eggs often cost more, it's simply because brown-feathered hens are bigger and more expensive to raise. You may see some egg cartons labeled with "Omega-3" indicators or other similar wording; these eggs are sourced from hens that are fed a special seed diet designed to raise the level of omega-3 fatty acids deposited into their eggs. You'll find more information about egg carton labels and marketing language below. Should I only eat egg whites? If you eat eggs more than once a day ( [vegetarians and flexitarians](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/health/diet-nutrition/a29538790/what-is-the-flexitarian-diet/), listen up!), swapping egg whites in place of whole eggs could be a great way to enjoy their flavor profile while dodging extra cholesterol. But don't cut out whole eggs if you enjoy them occasionally throughout the week. The yolks contain most of the essential nutrients reviewed here, and the fat in yolks helps your body absorb these vitamins and minerals. Plus, the yolk holds 40% of the protein found in eggs in the first place. Preparation Tips: Current health guidelines show that eating an egg each day does not have detrimental health effects. They can safely stay in your refrigerator without a loss of quality for three to five weeks after purchase, making eggs a great staple for so many [quick and nutritious meals](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/food-recipes/easy/g428/easy-egg-recipes/). claims can be confusing. Here's what all of those designations actually say. - Cage-Free: According to [the USDA](https://www.usda.gov/media/blog/2016/09/13/usda-graded-cage-free-eggs-all-theyre-cracked-be), cage-free hens must be housed in a building, room, or enclosed area with unlimited access to food and water. Cage-free does NOT mean that the hens have access to the outdoors. - Free-Range: Free-range hens must be housed in a building, room, or area with unlimited access to food and water. However, these hens must have continuous access to the outdoors during their laying cycle. This outdoor area may be fenced (in [a backyard or garden](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/home/gardening/advice/g1007/backyard-decorating/)if raised on a heritage farm!) and/or covered with netting. - Pasture-Raised: This term is not currently regulated by the USDA, but pasture-raised eggs should mean that the hens spend most of their life outdoors, with a fair amount of space to roam in addition to barn access. The hens can eat a diet of worms, insects, and grass, along with their feed, which replicates a chicken's natural diet and environment. Look for the [HFAC's Certified Humane Label](https://certifiedhumane.org/). - Farm-Fresh or "All-Natural": These labels aren't subject to federal regulation, nor do they convey a specific meaning. They're often used for marketing purposes, [per the USDA](https://www.google.com/search?q=all+nautral+eggs+usda&oq=all+nautral+eggs+usda&aqs=chrome..69i57j33l2.3058j0j4&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8). - No Hormones Added: Contrary to popular belief, the egg industry [does not use hormones](https://www2.illinois.gov/sites/agr/Consumers/EggInspection/Pages/Egg-Carton-Labeling-Terms.aspx#:~:text=If%20the%20chicken%20is%20fed,the%20production%20of%20shell%20eggs.)in the production of shell eggs, no matter if the label says this or not. - Antibiotic-Free: Similarly, all eggs produced in the U.S. are antibiotic-free, even if it's not specified on the carton. If hens become ill, a veterinarian can administer antibiotics, but subsequent eggs during this period would not be used for human consumption, according to [FDA regulations](https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/phasing-out-certain-antibiotic-use-farm-animals). - Vegetarian-Fed: According [to USDA rules](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/wcm/connect/6fe3cd56-6809-4239-b7a2-bccb82a30588/RaisingClaims.pdf?MOD=AJPERES), the egg producer using this claim must maintain documentation that the source hens do not eat any animal byproducts. However, chickens in the wild are omnivores (i.e., not vegetarian) and get most of their protein from worms and insects. - Gluten-Free: All eggs are naturally gluten-free. If the hens producing the eggs are fed a gluten-containing grain, the gluten is broken down during digestion and not passed on to the eggs. - Organic: In order to certify eggs as "organic," the hen's feed must be grown without most synthetic chemicals. 100% of the ingredients must be certified organic, and the hens must be free-range; the use of antibiotics and growth hormones are also prohibited. Management must present supporting documentation from an accredited certifying agent to the USDA to verify that the flock is organic. - Zero Trans Fats: This claim indicates that an egg contains less than 0.5 grams of trans fatty acids, which is true of all eggs. - AA, A or B: You may have noticed that eggs are graded as AA, A, or B, in descending order of quality. According [to the USDA](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/food-safety-education/get-answers/food-safety-fact-sheets/egg-products-preparation/shell-eggs-from-farm-to-table/CT_Index/!ut/p/a1/jZFRT4MwEMc_DY-lRebCfCMkZqADl6nreFkKXAtJoaTtRP301vk0s-muL3e93z93_ReXmOJyYG-dYLZTA5PfdTnfkzWZB4uEZMUiuCdp_rouHpKERJtbB-z-APLwSv2FiMl_-uyKATd6lawELkdmW9QNXGEqwCI2mAm0wZQr1SDDONgPxFltkWkBrGuAEGjUqjnU1rgERqaPxmDqCCmR6xvEteqdTPfIKmRZJQHT5HmfDg284y0uTxckgTtpHm5myywPSTH7DZxx8Ae4bJHzQEhVHb9rFw9VGLnHauCgQfsH7a5ba0dz5xGPTNPkC6WEBL9WvUfOSVplLKanJB77F_r5GC9J99RvIxN_Adm-j2M!/#15)and the American Egg Board, there is no difference in nutritional values. Grading is based on standards of appearance, such as the conditions of the white or yolk and the cleanliness and soundness of the shell. *With additional reporting by [Jaclyn London, M.S., R.D., C.D.N.](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/author/11834/jaclyn-london-ms-rd-cdn/) Zee Krstic is a health editor for Good Housekeeping, where he covers health and nutrition news, decodes diet and fitness trends and reviews the best products in the wellness aisle. Prior to joining GH in 2019, Zee fostered a nutrition background as an editor at Cooking Light and is continually developing his grasp of holistic health through collaboration with leading academic experts and clinical care providers. He has written about food and dining for Time, among other publications.
